2.rationale:
Let’s double‐check our situation. Our snake (ID 2) currently shows its head at (6,9). The board (with X increasing to the right and Y increasing upward) shows this row at y = 9:
  . . . . . . 2 T A .
That means:
 • (6,9) is our head (“2”)
 • (7,9) is part of our body (“T”)
 • (8,9) is an apple (“A”)

Our enemy snake (snake #1) is at (7,7), and the other apples are at (5,7), (2,6), (6,2), and (9,1).

From our head at (6,9) our possible moves are:
 • UP → (6,10). That’s off the board (since the board goes from 0 to 9), so we can’t go UP.
 • RIGHT → (7,9). That square is occupied by our own body (“T”), and moving there would mean death.
 • LEFT → (5,9). Row 9, column 5 is “.” (empty), so it’s safe.
 • DOWN → (6,8). Row 8 (which reads “. . . . . . . T . .”) tells us that (6,8) is “.” (empty) as well.

So our only safe choices are LEFT and DOWN. Now, which should we choose?

Looking at the apples:
 – The apple at (8,9) is to our right, but we cannot reach it because our body (the segment at (7,9)) blocks that direction.
 – The apple at (5,7) is down and to the left of our head. Whether we go LEFT first or DOWN first, we can later move to (5,7). For example:
  ○ If we move LEFT to (5,9), on the following turn we could move DOWN to (5,8) and then DOWN again to (5,7) to grab the apple.
  ○ Alternatively, if we move DOWN to (6,8), we could later move LEFT toward (5,7).
 
Between the two, moving LEFT first (to (5,9)) seems appealing because it moves us laterally toward the apple at (5,7) while keeping our head high on the board. This also helps avoid any accidental run‐in with the enemy snake located lower at (7,7). 

Next turn I’ll plan to head downward (or adjust as needed) so that I can reach the apple at (5,7) safely. 

Decided next move: LEFT.
